fields.text: Which of the following are parts of speech? (Select all that apply)

options.A: Noun
options.B: Adjective

fields.explanation: All options A through D are parts of speech. Option E is incorrect because it suggests these are the only parts of speech, but there are others like verbs and adverbs.

fields.text: Identify the correct sentence structure:

options.A: She quickly ran to the store, bought some milk, and then went home.
options.B: She quickly ran to the store bought some milk and then went home.
options.C: She quickly ran to the store, and bought some milk, and then went home.
options.D: She quickly ran to the store, and bought some milk and then went home.

fields.explanation: Option A correctly uses commas to separate items in a series and maintains parallel structure.

fields.text: Choose the correct verb form: If I _____ you, I would apologize immediately.

options.A: am
options.B: was

fields.explanation: 'Were' is used in the second conditional for hypothetical situations, even with 'I'.

fields.text: Select the sentence with correct punctuation:

options.A: The meeting is scheduled for Monday, June 5th at 2:00 PM; please be on time.
options.B: The meeting is scheduled for Monday, June 5th at 2:00 PM, please be on time.
options.C: The meeting is scheduled for Monday, June 5th at 2:00 PM please be on time.
options.D: The meeting is scheduled for Monday June 5th at 2:00 PM; please be on time.

fields.explanation: Option A correctly uses a semicolon to join two related independent clauses.

fields.text: Identify the type of sentence: Although it was raining, we decided to go for a walk.

options.A: Simple sentence
options.B: Compound sentence

fields.explanation: This is a complex sentence because it contains one independent clause and one dependent clause.

fields.text: Identify and correct the error: She don't like coffee.

options.A: She doesn't likes coffee.
options.B: She don't likes coffee.

fields.explanation: The correct form is 'doesn't like' because 'she' is third person singular and requires 'does' for negative present simple.

fields.text: Combine these sentences using 'although': It was raining. We went to the park.

options.A: Although it was raining, we went to the park.
options.B: We went to the park although it was raining.
options.C: It was raining, although we went to the park.
options.D: Both A and B are correct

fields.explanation: Both A and B are grammatically correct ways to combine the sentences using 'although', with the dependent clause either at the beginning or end of the sentence.

fields.text: Which sentence is in the passive voice?

options.A: The teacher gave us homework.
options.B: We were given homework by the teacher.
options.C: The homework is on the desk.

fields.explanation: The sentence 'We were given homework by the teacher' is in passive voice because the subject receives the action (were given) rather than performing it.

fields.text: Choose the correct verb form: If I _____ you, I would study harder for the test.

options.A: am
options.B: was

fields.explanation: In second conditional sentences (unreal or hypothetical situations), we use 'were' for all subjects in the 'if' clause, even with 'I' and 'he/she/it'.

fields.text: Which words are adverbs in this sentence? 'He quickly ran to the store yesterday.'

options.A: quickly, store
options.B: ran, store

fields.explanation: 'Quickly' describes how he ran (adverb of manner) and 'yesterday' tells when he ran (adverb of time).

fields.text: Choose the sentence with the correct word order:

options.A: Always she is late for school.
options.B: She is always late for school.
options.C: She always is late for school.
options.D: She is late always for school.

fields.explanation: The adverb of frequency 'always' should come after the verb 'to be' in simple present tense.

fields.text: Which sentence uses the present perfect continuous tense correctly?

options.A: I have been working here since 2020.
options.B: I worked here since 2020.

fields.explanation: The present perfect continuous is used with 'have/has been + present participle' to talk about actions that started in the past and continue to the present.

fields.text: Identify the type of conditional in this sentence: 'If it rains tomorrow, we will cancel the picnic.'

options.A: Zero conditional
options.B: First conditional

fields.explanation: This is a first conditional, which is used for real and possible situations in the future. The structure is: If + present simple, will + base verb.

fields.text: Choose the correct relative pronoun: 'The book _____ I borrowed from the library is very interesting.'

options.A: who
options.B: which

fields.explanation: 'Which' is used to refer to things (the book), while 'who' is for people, 'where' for places, and 'when' for time.

fields.text: Which sentence is punctuated correctly?

options.A: I need to buy eggs, milk, bread, and cheese.
options.B: I need to buy eggs, milk, bread and cheese.
options.C: I need to buy eggs milk, bread, and cheese.
options.D: I need to buy, eggs, milk, bread and cheese.

fields.explanation: The Oxford comma (the comma before 'and' in a list) is used here, which is a matter of style but helps prevent ambiguity.

fields.text: Choose the correct form of the verb: 'By the time we arrived, the movie _____.' (to start)

options.A: started
options.B: had started

fields.explanation: The past perfect (had + past participle) is used to show that one past action (the movie starting) happened before another past action (our arrival).

fields.text: Which sentence uses the correct order of adjectives?

options.A: She bought a beautiful blue silk dress.
options.B: She bought a blue beautiful silk dress.
options.C: She bought a silk beautiful blue dress.
options.D: She bought a blue silk beautiful dress.

fields.explanation: The correct order is opinion (beautiful) + color (blue) + material (silk) + noun (dress).

fields.text: Choose the correct tag question: 'You've seen that movie, _____?

options.A: have you
options.B: haven't you

fields.explanation: The main clause is positive ('You've seen'), so the tag should be negative ('haven't you'). We use the same auxiliary verb as in the main clause.

fields.text: Which sentence uses 'used to' correctly?

options.A: I use to play tennis when I was younger.
options.B: I used to played tennis when I was younger.
options.C: I used to play tennis when I was younger.
options.D: I was used to play tennis when I was younger.

fields.explanation: 'Used to' is followed by the base form of the verb to talk about past habits or states that are no longer true.

fields.text: Choose the correct form: 'I wish I _____ how to swim when I was younger.'

options.A: learned
options.B: had learned

fields.explanation: We use 'had + past participle' (past perfect) after 'wish' to talk about regrets about the past.

fields.text: Which sentence contains a non-defining relative clause?

options.A: The book which is on the table is mine.
options.B: The book, which is on the table, is mine.
options.C: The book that is on the table is mine.
options.D: The book is on the table and it's mine.

fields.explanation: A non-defining relative clause adds extra information and is separated by commas. It can be removed without changing the essential meaning of the sentence.

fields.text: Choose the correct form: 'By next year, I _____ English for five years.'

options.A: will study
options.B: will be studying

fields.explanation: We use the future perfect continuous to talk about the duration of an action that will be in progress before a specific time in the future.

fields.text: Which sentence is in the subjunctive mood?

options.A: If I was rich, I would travel the world.
options.B: If I were rich, I would travel the world.
options.C: If I am rich, I will travel the world.
options.D: I was rich and traveled the world.

fields.explanation: The subjunctive mood uses 'were' instead of 'was' for all subjects in hypothetical or contrary-to-fact situations.

fields.text: Choose the correct form: 'I'd rather you _____ that again.'

options.A: don't do
options.B: didn't do

fields.explanation: After 'would rather', we use the past simple to talk about preferences regarding other people's actions.

fields.text: Which sentence contains a dangling modifier?

options.A: Running to catch the bus, my bag fell open.
options.B: While I was running to catch the bus, my bag fell open.
options.C: My bag fell open while I was running to catch the bus.
options.D: As I ran to catch the bus, my bag fell open.

fields.explanation: In sentence A, the phrase 'Running to catch the bus' incorrectly modifies 'my bag' instead of 'I', creating a dangling modifier.

fields.text: Choose the correct form: 'If he _____ the train, he would be here by now.'

options.A: caught
options.B: had caught

fields.explanation: This is a third conditional (unreal past condition), which uses 'if + past perfect, would have + past participle'.

fields.text: Which sentence is an example of reported speech?

options.A: 'I will call you tomorrow,' she said.
options.B: She said that she would call me the next day.

fields.explanation: Reported speech reports what someone said without using their exact words, often with verb tense changes and time expression adjustments.

fields.text: Choose the correct form: 'I'm looking forward to _____ you at the party.'

options.A: see
options.B: seeing

fields.explanation: After the phrase 'looking forward to', we use a gerund (verb+ing).

fields.text: Which sentence uses the correct article?

options.A: She is a honest person.
options.B: She is an honest person.

fields.explanation: We use 'an' before words that begin with a vowel sound. 'Honest' starts with a silent 'h', so it sounds like it starts with a vowel.

fields.text: Choose the correct form: 'This is the house _____ I was born.'

options.A: which
options.B: where

fields.explanation: 'Where' is used to refer to a place in a relative clause when the place is the object of the verb or preposition.

fields.text: Which sentence is in the passive voice?

options.A: The committee will announce the results tomorrow.
options.B: The results will be announced tomorrow.
options.C: They will announce the results tomorrow.
options.D: We will hear the results tomorrow.

fields.explanation: In the passive voice, the subject receives the action. The structure is: subject + be + past participle + (by + agent).

fields.text: Choose the correct form: 'I wish I _____ to the party last night.'

options.A: went
options.B: had gone

fields.explanation: We use 'had + past participle' after 'wish' to express regret about something that happened or didn't happen in the past.

fields.text: Which sentence contains a non-defining relative clause?

options.A: The man who lives next door is a doctor.
options.B: My brother, who lives in London, is visiting us.
options.C: The book that I'm reading is very interesting.
options.D: The city where I was born is very beautiful.

fields.explanation: A non-defining relative clause adds extra information and is separated by commas. It can be removed without changing the essential meaning of the sentence.

fields.text: Choose the correct form: 'By the time you arrive, I _____ cooking dinner.'

options.A: will finish
options.B: will have finished

fields.explanation: The future perfect (will have + past participle) is used to say that something will be completed before a specific time in the future.

fields.text: Which sentence is in the subjunctive mood?

options.A: If I was you, I would apologize.
options.B: If I were you, I would apologize.
options.C: If I am you, I will apologize.
options.D: I was you, so I apologized.

fields.explanation: The subjunctive mood uses 'were' instead of 'was' for all subjects in hypothetical or contrary-to-fact situations, such as giving advice with 'If I were you'.

fields.text: Which of the following sentences contain(s) a phrasal verb? (Select all that apply)

options.A: I ran into my old friend at the mall.
options.B: She looked after her younger brother.
options.C: He quickly ran to the store.
options.D: They put off the meeting until next week.

fields.explanation: Options A, B, and D contain phrasal verbs: 'ran into' (met by chance), 'looked after' (took care of), and 'put off' (postponed). Option C has a verb and a preposition but doesn't form a phrasal verb.

fields.text: Choose the correct form: 'I suggest that he _____ to the doctor immediately.'

options.A: go
options.B: goes

fields.explanation: After verbs like 'suggest', 'recommend', 'demand', etc., we use the base form of the verb in the that-clause.

fields.text: Which of the following sentences is/are correct? (Select all that apply)

options.A: Neither John nor his friends is coming to the party.
options.B: The committee are divided in their opinions.
options.C: Each of the students has completed their assignment.
options.D: The news are very interesting today.

fields.explanation: Option B is correct because 'committee' can be treated as plural when referring to its members. Option C is correct with 'each' taking a singular verb. Option A is incorrect (should be 'are' to agree with 'friends'). Option D is incorrect ('news' is uncountable and takes a singular verb).

fields.text: Choose the correct sentence(s): (Select all that apply)

options.A: She speaks French fluently, doesn't she?
options.B: Let's go for a walk, shall we?
options.C: You won't be late, will you?

fields.explanation: Options A, B, and C use correct tag questions. Option D is incorrect; it should be 'aren't I?' instead of 'amn't I?' which is not standard English.

fields.text: Identify the sentence(s) with incorrect use of articles: (Select all that apply)

options.A: She is the best student in the class.
options.B: I saw a elephant at the zoo.
options.C: He plays the guitar very well.
options.D: She is doctor at the local hospital.

fields.explanation: Option B is incorrect because it should be 'an elephant'. Option D is incorrect because it should be 'a doctor'. Options A and C are correct.

fields.text: Which of the following sentences use(s) the past perfect tense correctly? (Select all that apply)

options.A: After I had finished my homework, I went to bed.
options.B: She had already left when I arrived.
options.C: I had seen that movie last week.
options.D: He told me he has been to Paris.

fields.explanation: Options A and B correctly use the past perfect to show that one action was completed before another in the past. Option C incorrectly uses past perfect with a specific time expression. Option D uses present perfect in reported speech, which should be past perfect ('had been').

fields.text: Choose the correct form(s) to complete the sentence: 'I wish I _____ how to swim when I was younger.' (Select all that apply)

options.A: had learned
options.B: learned

fields.explanation: The correct form is 'had learned' (past perfect) to express regret about something that didn't happen in the past. The other options are grammatically incorrect in this context.

fields.text: Which of the following sentences contain(s) a non-defining relative clause? (Select all that apply)

options.A: My brother, who lives in Canada, is a doctor.
options.B: The book which is on the table is mine.
options.C: Mr. Smith, whose car was stolen, is my neighbor.
options.D: The students who study hard will pass the exam.

fields.explanation: Options A and C contain non-defining relative clauses (set off by commas) that provide extra information. Options B and D contain defining relative clauses that are essential to the meaning of the sentence.

fields.text: Choose the correct form(s) to complete the sentence: 'By this time next year, I _____ my degree.' (Select all that apply)

options.A: will complete
options.B: will have completed

fields.explanation: The future perfect tense ('will have completed') is used to indicate that an action will be completed before a specific time in the future. The other options are either incorrect or less appropriate in this context.

fields.text: Which of the following sentences is/are examples of the second conditional? (Select all that apply)

options.A: If it rains, we will stay at home.
options.B: If I won the lottery, I would travel the world.
options.C: If I had known, I would have told you.
options.D: If I were you, I would apologize.

fields.explanation: Options B and D are examples of the second conditional, which is used for hypothetical or unlikely situations in the present or future. Option A is first conditional (real possibility), and option C is third conditional (unreal past).

fields.text: Identify the sentence(s) with correct subject-verb agreement: (Select all that apply)

options.A: The team is playing well this season.
options.B: The team are arguing among themselves.
options.C: The news are very interesting today.
options.D: The police are investigating the crime.

fields.explanation: Options A, B, and D are correct. 'Team' can be singular (A) or plural (B) depending on whether you're referring to it as a unit or as individuals. 'Police' is always plural. Option C is incorrect because 'news' is uncountable and takes a singular verb.

fields.text: Which of the following sentences use(s) reported speech correctly? (Select all that apply)

options.A: She said that she is going to the store.
options.B: He told me that he had finished his work.
options.C: They said they will come to the party.
options.D: She said she had seen that movie the previous week.

fields.explanation: Options B and D correctly use backshifted tenses in reported speech. Option A is incorrect because 'is going' should be 'was going' in reported speech. Option C is incorrect because 'will' should be 'would' in reported speech.

fields.text: Choose the correct form(s) of the verb: 'I would rather you _____ that.' (Select all that apply)

options.A: don't do
options.B: didn't do

fields.explanation: After 'would rather', we use the past simple to talk about preferences regarding other people's actions. The correct form is 'didn't do'.

fields.text: Which of the following sentences contain(s) a gerund? (Select all that apply)

options.A: Swimming is good exercise.
options.B: I enjoy reading books.

fields.explanation: Options A, B, and C contain gerunds (verb+ing used as a noun). 'Swimming' is the subject, 'reading' is the object of 'enjoy', and 'flying' is the object of the preposition 'of'. Option D contains an infinitive ('to travel').

fields.text: Which of the following sentences is/are examples of the passive voice? (Select all that apply)

options.A: The book was written by J.K. Rowling.
options.B: The teacher gave us a lot of homework.
options.C: The window was broken by the ball.
options.D: They are building a new school.

fields.explanation: Options A and C are in the passive voice, where the subject receives the action. Options B and D are in the active voice, where the subject performs the action.
